       AN ACT to amend the criminal procedure law, and the social services  law
         in  relation  to authorizing the review of sealed juvenile records for
         persons applying to serve as a foster or adoptive parent

         THE PEOPLE OF THE STATE OF NEW YORK, REPRESENTED IN SENATE AND  ASSEM-
       BLY, DO ENACT AS FOLLOWS:

    1    Section  1. Section 720.35 of the criminal procedure law is amended by
    2  adding a new subdivision 5 to read as follows:
    3    5. NOTWITHSTANDING SUBDIVISION TWO OF THIS SECTION, WHENEVER A  PERSON
    4  IS  ADJUDICATED  A YOUTHFUL OFFENDER AND THE CONVICTION THAT WAS VACATED
    5  AND REPLACED BY THE YOUTHFUL OFFENDER FINDING WAS FOR A SEX  OFFENSE  AS
    6  THAT  TERM  IS  DEFINED  IN SECTION 120.40 OF THE PENAL LAW, ALL RECORDS
    7  PERTAINING TO THE YOUTHFUL OFFENDER ADJUDICATION SHALL  BE  INCLUDED  IN
    8  THOSE  RECORDS  AND  REPORTS THAT MAY BE OBTAINED BY THE COMMISSIONER OF
    9  THE OFFICE OF CHILDREN AND FAMILY SERVICES IN  ORDER  TO  PERFORM  BACK-
   10  GROUND  CHECKS PURSUANT TO SECTIONS THREE HUNDRED SEVENTY-EIGHT-A, THREE
   11  HUNDRED NINETY-B, AND THREE HUNDRED NINETY-E OF THE SOCIAL SERVICES LAW.
   12    S 2. Subdivision 2 of section 378-a of  the  social  services  law  is
   13  amended by adding a new paragraph (a-1) to read as follows:
   14    (A-1)  THE  CRIMINAL HISTORY RECORD CHECK REQUIRED BY THIS SUBDIVISION
   15  SHALL INCLUDE A REVIEW FOR ANY CONVICTIONS VACATED  AND  REPLACED  BY  A
   16  YOUTHFUL OFFENDER FINDING FOR A SEX OFFENSE WHICH MAY BE OBTAINED BY THE
   17  COMMISSIONER  OF  THE OFFICE OF CHILDREN AND FAMILY SERVICES PURSUANT TO
   18  SUBDIVISION 5 OF SECTION 720.35 OF THE CRIMINAL PROCEDURE LAW.
   19    S 3. This act shall take effect immediately.

memo:
BILL NUMBER:S2469

TITLE OF BILL:
An act to amend the criminal procedure law, and the social services law
in relation to authorizing the review of sealed juvenile records for
persons applying to serve as a foster or adoptive parent

PURPOSE OR GENERAL IDEA OF BILL:
To ensure that prospective foster and adoptive parents or those seeking
employment from licensed caregivers receive a thorough background check
that includes juvenile convictions for sex offenses.

SUMMARY OF PROVISIONS:
Section 1. Section 720.35 of the criminal procedure law is amended by
adding a new subdivision 5 to require that all records and reports
related to a sex offense conviction as a youthful offender shall be
provided to the commissioner of children and family services in order to
perform background checks.

Section 2. Subdivision 2 of section 378-a of the social services law is
amended by adding a new paragraph (a-1) that mandates a review of the
youthful offender records referenced above as a part of the background
check process for foster and adoptive parents or employed by a licensed
caregiver.

JUSTIFICATION:
While New York State Law provides stringent background check guidelines
for prospective adoptive and foster parents or those seeking employment
with a licensed caregiver, these guidelines do not allow a review of
convictions that may have occurred as a youthful offender. This bill
would close a dangerous loophole in the law that allows individuals who
committed criminal sex offenses as a minor to hide those convictions
from the office of children and family services when records are
reviewed pursuant to an adoption or foster parenting situation or when
seeking employment from a licensed caregiver. This bill will allow the
Commissioner of Children and Family Services in each county in New York
State to examine any youthful offender conviction for a sex offense
before deciding if an individual is fit to serve as a foster or adoptive
parent or be employed by a licensed caregiver.

Sadly, we have seen cases around the State including in Western New
York, where individuals have committed sex offenses as juveniles, and
still been allowed to act as a foster or adoptive parent or work in a
daycare setting.  This situation is unacceptable because it places chil-
dren in harm's way. This bill would ensure that these types of situ-
ations never happen again.

PRIOR LEGISLATIVE HISTORY:
This is a new bill.

FISCAL IMPLICATIONS:

None.

EFFECTIVE DATE:
This act shall take effect immediately.
